articles.headline: How Does Warren Buffett Get Married? Frugally, It Turns Out
articles.snippet: The marriage of Warren E. Buffett to his longtime companion had the financial world abuzz, even if it did not move markets.
articles.abstract: The marriage of Warren E. Buffett to his longtime companion had the financial world abuzz, even if it did not move markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: It did not move markets, and Berkshire Hathaway shares barely budged, but the marriage of Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, to his longtime companion, Astrid Menks, had the financial world all abuzz yesterday.
articles.byline: By Jeff Bailey and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Lockheed Wins Job of Building Next Spaceship
articles.snippet: The NASA decision is likely to change the dynamics of the space business, setting Lockheed up to be the dominant player in space exploration.
articles.abstract: The NASA decision is likely to change the dynamics of the space business, setting Lockheed up to be the dominant player in space exploration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 — Lockheed Martin won a multibillion-dollar contract from NASA on Thursday to build the nation’s next spaceship for human flight, a craft called Orion that is to replace the space shuttle and eventually carry astronauts to the moon and beyond.
articles.byline: By Warren E. Leary and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: Where’s Mao? Chinese Revise History Books
articles.snippet: China is abandoning the Marxist template that has dominated the nation’s history textbooks since the 1950’s.
articles.abstract: China is abandoning the Marxist template that has dominated the nation’s history textbooks since the 1950’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Aug. 31 — When high school students in Shanghai crack their history textbooks this fall they may be in for a surprise. The new standard world history text drops wars, dynasties and Communist revolutions in favor of colorful tutorials on economics, technology, social customs and globalization.

articles.headline: California Plan to Cut Gases Splits Industry
articles.snippet: While high-tech companies have lined up behind the state’s recent pledge to curb carbon emissions, some in basic industries say it will force energy-intensive businesses out of state.
articles.abstract: While high-tech companies have lined up behind the state’s recent pledge to curb carbon emissions, some in basic industries say it will force energy-intensive businesses out of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: After becoming chief executive of PG&E last year, Peter Darbee met with a large number of leading climate scientists, he said, to make up his own mind about global warming.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: If Boomers Have It All, What’s Left?
articles.snippet: Baby boomers may be known as the generation that took it all, leaving their successors to take on the risks they did not have to accept for themselves.
articles.abstract: Baby boomers may be known as the generation that took it all, leaving their successors to take on the risks they did not have to accept for themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE baby boom generation may be known to history as the one that took it all, leaving their successors to pay the bills and take on the risks that the boomers did not have to accept for themselves.

articles.headline: Generic of Plavix Is Blocked
articles.snippet: In a patent dispute, a federal judge ordered a Canadian company to stop distributing its generic version of the anticlotting drug Plavix.
articles.abstract: In a patent dispute, a federal judge ordered a Canadian company to stop distributing its generic version of the anticlotting drug Plavix.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a Canadian company yesterday to stop distributing its generic version of the blockbuster anticlotting drug Plavix, granting a reprieve to Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, which co-market the brand-name drug.

articles.headline: A Younger India Is Flexing Its Industrial Brawn
articles.snippet: For decades, India focused on its domestic economy and grew more slowly. But all that is starting to change.
articles.abstract: For decades, India focused on its domestic economy and grew more slowly. But all that is starting to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUNE, India — India’s economic advancement no longer rests on telephone call centers and computer programmers.

articles.headline: Voters Hearing Countless Ways of Saying ‘Sorry’
articles.snippet: These are sorry days in American politics.     The Maryland comptroller, William Donald Schaefer, a former governor and Baltimore mayor, released a radio advertisement on Wednesday in which he apologized to anyone he had offended in his 50-year ca...
articles.abstract: These are sorry days in American politics.     The Maryland comptroller, William Donald Schaefer, a former governor and Baltimore mayor, released a radio advertisement on Wednesday in which he apologized to anyone he had offended in his 50-year career, sins that ranged from ogling a woman at a public meeting to complaining that immigrants were not learning English fast enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - These are sorry days in American politics.

articles.headline: A Younger India Is Flexing Its Industrial Brawn
articles.snippet: India's economic advancement no longer rests on telephone call centers and computer programmers.     Among villages with thatch-roofed huts and dirt roads on the outskirts of this city in central India, John Deere and LG Electronics have recently ...
articles.abstract: India's economic advancement no longer rests on telephone call centers and computer programmers.     Among villages with thatch-roofed huts and dirt roads on the outskirts of this city in central India, John Deere and LG Electronics have recently built factories turning out tractors and color television sets for sale in India and for export to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUNE, India - India's economic advancement no longer rests on telephone call centers and computer programmers.

articles.headline: California Plan to Cut Gases Splits Industry
articles.snippet: After becoming chief executive of PG&E last year, Peter Darbee met with a large number of leading climate scientists, he said, to make up his own mind about global warming.      As a result of his wide inquiries, PG&E, the parent of the Pacific Ga...
articles.abstract: After becoming chief executive of PG&E last year, Peter Darbee met with a large number of leading climate scientists, he said, to make up his own mind about global warming.      As a result of his wide inquiries, PG&E, the parent of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, which serves Northern California and is one of the nation's largest energy utilities, broke away from the industry pack to support sweeping efforts to reduce the greenhouse-gas emissions that are widely blamed for global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: After becoming chief executive of PG&E last year, Peter Darbee met with a large number of leading climate scientists, he said, to make up his own mind about global warming.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Generic of Plavix Is Blocked
articles.snippet: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a Canadian company yesterday to stop distributing its generic version of the blockbuster anticlotting drug Plavix, granting a reprieve to Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, which co-market the brand-name ...
articles.abstract: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a Canadian company yesterday to stop distributing its generic version of the blockbuster anticlotting drug Plavix, granting a reprieve to Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, which co-market the brand-name drug.      The Plavix marketers had seen a drastic erosion of their United States sales since the Canadian company, Apotex, introduced its generic version on Aug. 8 in a challenge to the patent held by the big companies. Analysts say that the large supplies of the generic drug already on the market could continue to impinge on sales of Plavix for several months.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a Canadian company yesterday to stop distributing its generic version of the blockbuster anticlotting drug Plavix, granting a reprieve to Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, which co-market the brand-name drug.

articles.headline: Lockheed Wins Job of Building Next Spaceship
articles.snippet: Lockheed Martin won a multibillion-dollar contract from NASA on Thursday to build the nation's next spaceship for human flight, a craft called Orion that is to replace the space shuttle and eventually carry astronauts to the moon and beyond.     T...
articles.abstract: Lockheed Martin won a multibillion-dollar contract from NASA on Thursday to build the nation's next spaceship for human flight, a craft called Orion that is to replace the space shuttle and eventually carry astronauts to the moon and beyond.     The much-awaited announcement was a major victory for Lockheed and a startling setback for its rival, a joint venture of Boeing and Northrop Grumman.
articles.byline: By Warren E. Leary and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: In Latest Push, Bush Cites Risk in Quitting Iraq
articles.snippet: President Bush said Thursday that withdrawing now from Iraq would leave Americans at risk of terrorist attacks ''in the streets of our own cities,'' and he cast the struggle against Islamic extremists as the costly but necessary successor to the b...
articles.abstract: President Bush said Thursday that withdrawing now from Iraq would leave Americans at risk of terrorist attacks ''in the streets of our own cities,'' and he cast the struggle against Islamic extremists as the costly but necessary successor to the battles of the last century against Nazism and Communism.     ''The war we fight today is more than a military conflict,'' Mr. Bush said in a speech to veterans at an American Legion convention here. ''It is the decisive ideological struggle of the 21st century.''
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 31 - President Bush said Thursday that withdrawing now from Iraq would leave Americans at risk of terrorist attacks "in the streets of our own cities," and he cast the struggle against Islamic extremists as the costly but necessary successor to the battles of the last century against Nazism and Communism.
articles.byline: By Anne E. Kornblut and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: If Boomers Have It All, What’s Left?
articles.snippet: THE baby boom generation may be known to history as the one that took it all, leaving their successors to pay the bills and take on the risks that the boomers did not have to accept for themselves.     A glaring example is in the world of pensions...
articles.abstract: THE baby boom generation may be known to history as the one that took it all, leaving their successors to pay the bills and take on the risks that the boomers did not have to accept for themselves.     A glaring example is in the world of pensions, where corporate executives and directors, many of them baby boomers, are reducing benefits for younger employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE baby boom generation may be known to history as the one that took it all, leaving their successors to pay the bills and take on the risks that the boomers did not have to accept for themselves.

articles.headline: How Does Warren Buffett Get Married? Frugally, It Turns Out
articles.snippet: It did not move markets, and Berkshire Hathaway shares barely budged, but the marriage of Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, to his longtime companion, Astrid Menks, had the financial world all abuzz yesterday.      Mr. Buffett and Ms. Menk...
articles.abstract: It did not move markets, and Berkshire Hathaway shares barely budged, but the marriage of Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, to his longtime companion, Astrid Menks, had the financial world all abuzz yesterday.      Mr. Buffett and Ms. Menks formalized a relationship of more than 20 years in a brief civil ceremony at his daughter's house in Omaha Wednesday afternoon.
articles.lead_paragraph: It did not move markets, and Berkshire Hathaway shares barely budged, but the marriage of Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, to his longtime companion, Astrid Menks, had the financial world all abuzz yesterday.
articles.byline: By Jeff Bailey and Eric Dash

articles.headline: On the Job, Nursing Mothers Find a 2-Class System
articles.snippet: When a new mother returns to Starbucks' corporate headquarters in Seattle after maternity leave, she learns what is behind the doors mysteriously marked ''Lactation Room.''      Whenever she likes, she can slip away from her desk and behind those ...
articles.abstract: When a new mother returns to Starbucks' corporate headquarters in Seattle after maternity leave, she learns what is behind the doors mysteriously marked ''Lactation Room.''      Whenever she likes, she can slip away from her desk and behind those doors, sit in a plush recliner and behind curtains, and leaf through InStyle magazine as she holds a company-supplied pump to her chest, depositing her breast milk in bottles to be toted home later.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a new mother returns to Starbucks' corporate headquarters in Seattle after maternity leave, she learns what is behind the doors mysteriously marked "Lactation Room."
